awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Investigating and Pinpointing the College Success Factors for First-Generation, Underrepresented College Students in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Students who are the first-generation in their family to attend college are increasingly the spotlight of educational research and reform seeking to broaden the participation of underrepresented students in higher education in general and engineering in particular. While growing research begins to illuminate the challenges these college students face, this research project attempts to break new grounds by making two key interventions. First, the investigators will apply an intersectional lens to understanding how the multiple dimensions that make a person's identity intersect (e.g., socioeconomic class, gender, race, ethnicity, disability, parental status, immigrant status, and rural vs. urban K-12 schooling, etc.) and how this intersection may positively influence the success of first-generation engineering students at various higher education institutional-types. Second, the investigators will take a capabilities approach to study what kinds of opportunities and strategies best support particular kinds of first-generation students, rather than focusing exclusively on their deficiencies and/or treating them as an undifferentiated group. Having this nuanced understanding will provide the foundation for more effective, targeted, and potentially transformative educational reforms to broaden the participation of first-generation students from multiple backgrounds in engineering. By more clearly identifying the factors leading to the success of such students, this research project has the potential to inspire educational transformations in admission decision-making, teaching, advising, and mentoring practices that are all likely to broadening the participation of first-generation students in engineering, especially among women and underrepresented groups in engineering. 

The investigators will use findings from a pilot ethnographic research on low-income, first-generation students and insights from the growing theoretical and scientific literature on first-generation students to develop a survey that will be given to students and alumni from across the U.S.. This will allow for an intersectional analysis of first-generation students' engineering experiences and the specific variables that contribute to their perseverance and successful entries into the job market and/or graduate school. This project addresses two major limitations of the existing theoretical and scientific research on first-generation students. First, the project will provide between- and within-group comparisons of first-generation students to obtain more nuanced understanding of how multiple factors influence their success in completing engineering degrees and transitioning to the engineering workforce. As the first large-scale intersectional analysis of first-generation student experiences in engineering, the project will add analytic clarity to a field that unevenly considers generational status along with socioeconomic class, race/ethnicity, and gender. It will also advance the literature  base by expanding the traditional demographic categories to include those that were salient for students in the preliminary ethnographic research, such as parental or immigrant status. Second, the research will identify if and how opportunities for students to apply their "funds of knowledge" (e.g., developed through their family and work experiences) inside of the engineering curriculum shapes their undergraduate success and graduation transitions. The project's findings will be disseminated to participating institutions, engineering educators at-large, and future generations of first-generation students through faculty and advisors.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the experiences of engineering students who are the first in their families to attend college. Rather than treating "first-gen" students as a single category, we aimed to better understand how these students' experiences varied by their gender, racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic background. These findings provide the foundation for our concrete recommendations for engineering educators seeking to better support first gen students. Dina Verdín led the development of the survey instrument and the data analysis and served as the first author on our journal articles and conference proceedings. Humanitarian engineering MS student Arielle Rainey assisted with the research on belongingness. Jessica Smith served as PI and Juan Lucena as co-PI.

We created and validated a quantitative survey that gathers information on students' interest in engineering; beliefs about their persistence, competence/performance in engineering, recognition by others as an engineer, and certainty of graduating with an engineering major; and feelings of classroom belongingness. We developed novel questions that examine students' funds of knowledge, or the skills and knowledge people develop through their daily work and family lives, but are infrequently recognized as knowledge in formal classroom settings. Viewing backgrounds as funds of knowledge is important for engineering educators and students because it emphasizes the value of the skills and knowledge that students who may not fit the stereotypical engineering demographic possess and can utilize to understanding and navigating the engineering curriculum and profession.

Our student pool includes 819 students from across the country who took our survey during the Fall 2018 semester. Of those, 378 (46%) identified as first-generation college students; 402 (49%) as white; 226 (28%) as Latino/a; 420 (51%) as female; and 267 (32%) as Pell grantees. The distribution of students who responded to our survey ranged from 125 (15%) first-year students, 157 (19%) second-year students, 205 (25%) third-year students, and 332 (41%) fourth-year or higher students Specifically, ten distinct funds of knowledge were developed and validated: tinkering knowledge from home, tinkering knowledge from work, connecting experiences, networks from family members, networks from college friends, networks from coworkers, networks from neighborhood friends, perspective taking, reading people, and mediating ability.

Our research indicates that for first gen students, tinkering knowledge from home is especially important for their views of themselves as engineers, their interest in engineering, and their belief about performing well and understanding engineering concepts. We also found that first-year students' tinkering knowledge from home supported their beliefs about doing well in their engineering coursework, which in turn supports their certainty of majoring in engineering. Seeing a connection between their home experiences and their engineering coursework and drawing from their home experiences to solve an engineering task both supported students' self-efficacy beliefs, interest, and certainty of majoring in engineering. Perspective taking had a direct connection to students' beliefs about performing well in engineering and understanding engineering content. No direct relationship was found between connecting experiences and classroom belonging, which may reflect that their funds of knowledge are not visible to or valued by their peers and professors. Additionally, no direct relationship was found between belonging and tinkering knowledge, mediational skills, perspective taking, or reading people. Rather, our research suggests that performance/competence beliefs can positively impact students' sense of belonging.

We found significant differences among first-gen students, however, when we analyzed by race, ethnicity, and gender. We found that both first-gen and continuing generation minoritized women were less likely to feel a sense of belonging in the classroom when compared to majority men. Neither groups of women believed that their instructors wanted them to succeed. There were, however, faculty support efforts that positively contributed to a sense of belonging in the classroom for minoritized women, including instructors' availability, knowing that they could ask instructors for help in course-related material, and when instructors fostered an atmosphere of mutual respect. Additionally, minoritized women felt a sense of classroom belonging when they could capitalize on their funds of knowledge to scaffold their learning. Our research points to the significance of validating messages from faculty for supporting belongingness among minoritized female students, as long as those messages are accompanied by students feeling recognized as an engineer.

Finally, Professor Verdín investigated how developing an engineering identity through the interplay between a sense of belonging and interest, recognition, and performance/competence beliefs supported women's persistence beliefs in engineering. Seeing oneself as an engineer, feeling a sense of belonging in their major, and belonging in the classroom did not support minoritized women's sense of certainty that they would complete their engineering degree. Their persistence was primarily positively influenced by their interest in engineering and their confidence in performing well in their coursework.

Our open source survey could be used by others to map students' funds of knowledge and assess changes in students' engineering identity as a result of connecting their funds of knowledge to engineering.


Last Modified: 09/10/2021
Modified by: Jessica M Smith
